title: Ditton River
text:
The Rivière Ditton is a tributary of the <a href="rivi%C3%A8re%20au%20Saumon%20%28Le%20Haut-Saint-Fran%C3%A7ois%29">rivière au Saumon</a>. This river flows in the municipalities of <a href="Chartierville%2C%20Quebec">Chartierville</a> and <a href="La%20Patrie%2C%20Quebec">La Patrie</a>, in the <a href="Le%20Haut-Saint-Fran%C3%A7ois%20Regional%20County%20Municipality">Le Haut-Saint-François Regional County Municipality</a>, in the administrative region of <a href="Estrie">Estrie</a>, in the <a href="provinces%20and%20territories%20of%20Canada">province</a> of <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>, in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>.
Forestry is the main economic activity in this valley; agriculture, second, especially in the lower part.
The surface of the Ditton River is usually frozen from mid-December to mid-March, except the rapids areas; however, safe circulation on the ice is generally from late December to early March.
Geography.
The hydrographic slopes neighboring the "Ditton River" are:
The Ditton River originates in the south of <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a> in the township of Emberton, in the White Mountains from the border between <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a> and <a href="New%20Hampshire">New Hampshire</a>, east of the Line Mountain () and east of "Third Connecticut Lake" located in the "Connecticut Lakes State Forest" in <a href="New%20Hampshire">New Hampshire</a>.
The course of the Ditton River descends on , according to the following segments:
The Ditton river flows on the south bank of the <a href="rivi%C3%A8re%20au%20Saumon%20%28Le%20Haut-Saint-Fran%C3%A7ois%29">rivière au Saumon</a>. Its confluence is located south of the <a href="Quebec%20Route%20212">route 212</a>, southwest of the intersection of this latter route with the <a href="Quebec%20Route%20257">route 257</a> of the village <a href="La%20Patrie%2C%20Quebec">La Patrie</a>.
Toponymy.
The term "Ditton" is a family name of British origin.
The toponym "Ditton" was taken from the name of an important village and civil parish in the <a href="Tonbridge%20and%20Malling">Tonbridge and Malling district</a> of <a href="Kent">Kent</a>, in <a href="England">England</a>. This toponym is also used in <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a> to designate the <a href="Ditton%20East%20River">Ditton East River</a> and the <a href="Ditton%20West%20River">Ditton West River</a>.
The toponym "rivière Ditton" was formalized on December 5, 1968, at the <a href="Commission%20de%20toponymie%20du%20Qu%C3%A9bec">Commission de toponymie du Québec</a>.
